title: 115_hr3998
content: The "Protect America Act of 2017" grants the Attorney General the authority to deny the sale, delivery, or transfer of firearms to known or suspected terrorists. It also requires information-sharing on attempted firearms purchases by these individuals and authorizes the investigation of known or suspected terrorists trying to buy firearms. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2017" amends Section 922(t) of title 18, United States Code, giving the Attorney General authority to take steps when a firearm transfer request involves a known or suspected terrorist. This includes confirming identity, notifying relevant agencies, and determining the individual's terrorist nexus. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2017" amends Section 922(t) of title 18, United States Code, allowing the Attorney General to investigate prospective firearm transferees for terrorism ties. The Attorney General can delay transfers for up to 72 hours and file emergency petitions to block transfers if there is probable cause of terrorist activity. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2017" allows the Attorney General to investigate prospective firearm transferees for terrorism ties. An emergency petition can be filed to prohibit firearm transfers if there is probable cause of terrorist activity. The term 'known or suspected terrorist' is defined as a person engaged in conduct related to terrorism or providing material support for terrorism. The term 'terrorism' includes international and domestic terrorism, as defined in section 2331. A person is not considered a known or suspected terrorist solely based on being in the terrorist screening database if their name was removed due to an error. The Attorney General is granted authority to deny explosives sales to known or suspected terrorists, require information-sharing on their attempted purchases, and authorize investigations into them. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" grants the Attorney General authority to deny explosives sales to known or suspected terrorists and investigate applicants with suspected ties to terrorism. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" allows the Attorney General to investigate and potentially deny explosives sales to individuals with suspected terrorism ties. This includes confirming or ruling out terrorism connections, notifying relevant agencies, and initiating investigations as needed. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" empowers the Attorney General to investigate and potentially deny explosives sales to individuals with suspected terrorism ties. An emergency petition can be filed in the district court to prohibit approval of an application if there is probable cause to believe an act of terrorism is being planned. The petition can only be granted after a hearing where the applicant has the opportunity to participate with counsel. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" allows the Attorney General to investigate and deny explosives sales to individuals with suspected terrorism ties. The term 'known or suspected terrorist' is defined as someone engaged in terrorism-related activities. The term 'terrorism' includes international and domestic terrorism. Being identified in the terrorist screening database does not automatically classify someone as a known or suspected terrorist. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" allows the Attorney General to investigate and deny explosives sales to individuals with suspected terrorism ties. The term 'known or suspected terrorist' is defined as someone engaged in terrorism-related activities, including international and domestic terrorism. If a person's name was erroneously included in the terrorist screening database, it can be removed. The amendments made by sections 2 and 3 of the "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2017" will expire after a 3-year period from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there will be reports submitted to Congress. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress within 18 months to 3 years after the enactment of the Act on petitions and court orders related to domestic and international terrorism, including the number of petitions filed, orders granted, denials, and outcomes of arrests. The Attorney General must report to Congress on petitions and court orders related to terrorism, including outcomes of deportation proceedings and multiple petitions filed against individuals. Within 90 days of this Act, the Attorney General must review and correct the terrorist watch list and no-fly list to remove any individuals erroneously listed or not suspected terrorists. A report detailing the actions taken must be submitted to Congress.
